honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE0050","attributes":[{"name":"General Education","code":"general_education","description":"This course is available as general education and normally taken outside the study area in which the student’s program is based. Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE0050 - Space Mining","description":"

Engineering is the application of scientific principles to solve real-world problems and is behind the rise of recent and world-changing technologies such as smartphones, electric cars and artificial intelligence. Space mining is possibly one of the most world-changing ideas and most of the focus has been on solving the engineering challenges. Some say that space mining is the way to create a society of limitless resources and change the way that the world can operate, others say that mining space resources will cause crashes in gold, platinum and multiple other markets, creating havoc here on Earth. Issues like these are why subjects like space mining are in need of people from other disciplines, to help understand all of the other problems in this and similar fields and how those problems might be solved.


In this course, we will explore what opportunities this and other world-changing engineering challenges have for those who are not engineers. Students will be taken through the engineering lifecycle of new technologies and encouraged to think about how their unique skills can be applied to these projects.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"410485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discipline-specific Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This report will have the student identify a problem in space mining that they want to address. The report will then showcase their solution, covering their problem-solving process and what challenges they encountered along the way. The way that they choose to address the problem is encouraged to be related to their own discipline of study.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c10485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c10485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d0485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Problem-solving Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This report will cover the work completed in the third workshop of this course and will be a short (3 pages or less) description of the solution, the problem-solving method, why the approach was taken and images/copies of slides/prototypes/models created to support the proposed solution. The purpose of this assessment is to have the students put in practice problem-solving that would assist an engineering project, as occurs on real large engineering projects across engineering disciplines. The students are encouraged to work in groups on the assessment, but this is not a requirement.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c10485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"590485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short video OR essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assessment, students will produce a one-minute video OR a 1000-word essay to speak about an idea that they have learned in the course material. The purpose of the assessment is to have students concisely describe a concept in their own words in a way that people from other disciplines can understand.

\n

The assessment has two different rubrics to reflect the different assessment types and the marks will be reviewed and compared between assessment types to ensure the rubric is effective for future offerings.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c10485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d90485afdb25bc50be4672f5f3961927","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/GENE0050.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: general education - faculty of engineering,space mining,novel mining systems,systems engineering
contentlets.description:
Engineering is the application of scientific principles to solve real-world problems and is behind the rise of recent and world-changing technologies such as smartphones, electric cars and artificial intelligence. Space mining is possibly one of the most world-changing ideas and most of the focus has been on solving the engineering challenges. Some say that space mining is the way to create a society of limitless resources and change the way that the world can operate, others say that mining space resources will cause crashes in gold, platinum and multiple other markets, creating havoc here on Earth. Issues like these are why subjects like space mining are in need of people from other disciplines, to help understand all of the other problems in this and similar fields and how those problems might be solved.

In this course, we will explore what opportunities this and other world-changing engineering challenges have for those who are not engineers. Students will be taken through the engineering lifecycle of new technologies and encouraged to think about how their unique skills can be applied to these projects.
contentlets.title: Space Mining

honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE1015","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE1015 - Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management","description":"

 


An introduction to Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by regional and corporate environmental managers to implement ESD principles in organisations and regions. These methods and tools include a range of environmental assessment techniques that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).

contentlets.description: An introduction to Ecologically Sustainable Development (ESD) principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by regional and corporate environmental managers to implement ESD principles in organisations and regions. These methods and tools include a range of environmental assessment techniques that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).

Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GENE1500","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."},{"name":"General Education","code":"general_education","description":"This course is available as general education and normally taken outside the study area in which the student’s program is based. Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GENE1500 - Creative Entrepreneurship","description":"

What is creativity? What is entrepreneurship? Why do they matter? In this course, you will identify, analyse and propose a solution to a meaningful unsolved problem in the world for an identified market segment. The course runs in an experiential mode, and you will form multidisciplinary teams to tackle their chosen problem, guided by entrepreneurship mentors and UNSW alumni who are running their own startup. Practical tools and protocols will be introduced for critically developing solution concepts, performing competitive analyses, building mindsets, skills, creativity and problem-solving, motivating and developing others, networking, building effective cross-disciplinary teams, designing experiments to validate concepts and rapid prototyping. You will then learn pitching and visual and graphic design skills, learning how to communicate influentially.


After this course, you will have (i) a changed mindset, so that you can experience the world and your entire study program from an entrepreneur’s perspective; (ii) sharpened skills in finding problems worth solving, mobilising people and resources to solve them, selling your ideas and skills and creating value; and (iii) a smaller step to creating your own first start-up, with mentors, support structures and fellow UNSW students to bring your ideas and companies to life.

This course can be taken by Faculty of Engineering students as a General Education course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8a0485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d2","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project: Present and Submit Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

 Present and Submit Group Project

Students in teams will be required to design a business model and pitch deck for a creative entrepreneurial venture that targets a problem space generated by the cohort (Individual Project A). This exercise is meant to tie together the course materials from each of the weeks in an innovative and imaginative way. The team based applied learning exercise simulates the activities that real entrepreneurs do when designing a venture.

Requirements: 5 minute pitch presentation plus 10 minutes Q&A.

Students will receive both a group component (50% of assessment value) and an individual component (50% of assessment value) in their mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"020485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"020485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"020485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0a0485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0a0485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e0485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Project B: Reflective Peer Feedback","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Reflective Peer Feedback (300 words)

Each student is randomly assigned 3 reports and videos from Individual Project A for them to provide structured feedback on.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"020485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"020485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"820485afdb25bc50be4672f5f39619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual Project A: Validating a Problem Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Written report (1400 words) + 2 minute video

Identify and analyse a meaningful unsolved problem in the world for an identified market segment. Use Customer Discovery methodology to present evidence that validates (or invalidates) your identified problem space. Critically reflect on this process

contentlets.description:
What is creativity? What is entrepreneurship? Why do they matter? In this course, you will identify, analyse and propose a solution to a meaningful unsolved problem in the world for an identified market segment. The course runs in an experiential mode, and you will form multidisciplinary teams to tackle their chosen problem, guided by entrepreneurship mentors and UNSW alumni who are running their own startup. Practical tools and protocols will be introduced for critically developing solution concepts, performing competitive analyses, building mindsets, skills, creativity and problem-solving, motivating and developing others, networking, building effective cross-disciplinary teams, designing experiments to validate concepts and rapid prototyping. You will then learn pitching and visual and graphic design skills, learning how to communicate influentially.

After this course, you will have (i) a changed mindset, so that you can experience the world and your entire study program from an entrepreneur’s perspective; (ii) sharpened skills in finding problems worth solving, mobilising people and resources to solve them, selling your ideas and skills and creating value; and (iii) a smaller step to creating your own first start-up, with mentors, support structures and fellow UNSW students to bring your ideas and companies to life.

This course can be taken by Faculty of Engineering students as a General Education course.
contentlets.title: Creative Entrepreneurship
